intro: Calochortus syntrophus, commonly known as the desert goldcup, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. It has basal leaves that are linear to lanceolate and often covered in fine hairs. Calochortus syntrophus is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens with well-drained soil.
